4a722ba9665fe3ebecdfcf04168ae596 (20:50): chrome has no problems with that
7be6005db42d173eb3635c22dc0c11f5 (20:53): Flanagan says the test expression must evaluate to true for the loop to execute
b98b14478fb4367c01a82fb1753d43d6 (20:54): maybe its true until proven false?
7be6005db42d173eb3635c22dc0c11f5 (21:02): I believe the ECMA spec states that it must evaluate to false to prevent execution
4a722ba9665fe3ebecdfcf04168ae596 (21:06): trying to find relevant code in v8 source

4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (21:11): ecma really needs to publish that thing in fucking html

59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (21:16): i dont, but at least i'm not subject to adobe loading anything, so thats a small win
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (21:17): what do ya'll think of Rafe's "save feeds" hew & cry?

18d23e7e3397f5ffebebd0fd268b2446 (21:20): ok. just put a slash befor msg. Got it.
7be6005db42d173eb3635c22dc0c11f5 (21:20): 59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73: I don't think RSS is going to go away, it drives traffic. Things that drive traffic will stay
4a722ba9665fe3ebecdfcf04168ae596 (21:21): 59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73, i had to deal with different rss/atom feeds a couple of days ago and it is such a mess
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (21:21): the question i found interesting from rafe's discussion was
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (21:21): what should a browser do with an RSS link?
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (21:21): http://nodeconf.com/ is a few days after jsconf .. both in portland.. FYI
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (21:22): which mirrors the question of what should a browser do with PDF
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (21:22): 4a722ba9665fe3ebecdfcf04168ae596: i havent clicked safarai's "feed" or "reader" button, what does it do?
38e5971429bb0f30aa410ac1ae0bb9a9 (21:22): 4a722ba9665fe3ebecdfcf04168ae596, Array - Lets you work with arrays. https://developer.mozilla.org/en/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array

4a722ba9665fe3ebecdfcf04168ae596 (21:23): 59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73, when you open a feed in safari, it just presents it in a nice way http://dl.dropbox.com/u/447925/Screenshots/ztbvqlafmofq.png
7be6005db42d173eb3635c22dc0c11f5 (21:24): I think Firefox has it right, treat a feed like any other page you can bookmark
4a722ba9665fe3ebecdfcf04168ae596 (21:24): although i don't like the fact that there is not easy way to get a feed source
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (21:25): building a feed reader into the browser is very much a "native pdf viewer" idea
7be6005db42d173eb3635c22dc0c11f5 (21:26): eh, not really, there isn't much after-market work to be done with pdfs
7be6005db42d173eb3635c22dc0c11f5 (21:26): use cases for a feed vary
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (21:26): agreed that the rss reader is an application, whereas a pdf viewer has more straightforward use cases
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (21:27): what alternatives can you see being built in to the browser?
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (21:27): if there isnt a builtin reader, do you just open a save as dialog box?  what _could_ the browser do?
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (21:27): what kind of extension points would you imagine to let the browser do more, do better?
7be6005db42d173eb3635c22dc0c11f5 (21:34): hmm, that will take some thinking

59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (21:36): i interpret as an open problem implicit in rafe's post, and a great issue to mull over.  letting the net/web bubble over beyonds & past just the browser is an interesting teaser.
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (21:36): i'll be an idling if you have any ideas.  will raise any thoughts that come to me. :)
7be6005db42d173eb3635c22dc0c11f5 (21:38): just so i understand, the frame of the question is for laypersons, not for those people already using a feed reader
